text: when I got the invitation I can't tell
you how excited that I was because I'll
guarantee you I know more than most
people up here about Henry Clay because
I knew I read at least 10 biographies of
clay and this morning when I got up I
was getting dressed I'm trying to figure
out the right what kind of tie am i
going to wear a day I pulled out this
tie with thoroughbreds on it because
Henry Clay was one of the first
thoroughbred breeders in Kentucky Henry
Clay was the first what I'll call strong
Speaker of the House the real leader of
the house when when our country was
founded and the Congress was put
together the first speakers over the
first 20 years or so we came out of the
English Parliament system and they were
more of a referee didn't have any real
power but clay was the first real
speaker of the house that had some power
his idea was now let me say it very
clearly his syllogism was the speaker
mr. speaker the speaker is the head of
the majority party see how this feels to
you the legislative majority but the
speaker is the head of the majority
party the legislative majority should
shape government ergo the speaker should
coordinate and direct government's
course you tell the president
the speaker Hastert let me ask you about
a the different ways that different
people approached the job Speaker
Boehner talked about how Henry Clay was
the first powerful speaker and it is a
command institution it has there's a lot
of power invested the majority to do to
get done what you want but within that
there are different styles I was talking
to Steve elmendorf a veteran aid on
Capitol Hill all of you guys doing he
said you've got your top down speakers
and your bottom up speakers and Gingrich
Pelosi right top down speaker clay top
down speakers and then you got your
bottom up speakers you Speaker Boehner
now with a different style talk a little
bit about the choice that you make in
how you're going to execute the job well
I think we all learn from our
predecessors and I hope these folks here
learned from their predecessors but
anyway good bad but I always had a
coaching philosophy that if the coach
was in the headlines every day the team
was in trouble if the teams in the
headlines every day teams doing pretty
good henry clay has a legacy in
washington he introduced the mint julep
to washington DC the Willard hotel so
well we're two hundred years from now
what are they going to talk about what
Speaker Boehner did to Washington DC
they'll know a couple hundred years from
now i have to say that when i became
speaker with all of our agenda that we
went forth when i said no more smoking
in the capital that got more news than
anything especially because mr. boehner
sort of has a tendency like you know she
was doing it for your own good they were
